On 11/25/05, Mark Baker <distobj@...> wrote:
>
> On 11/24/05, toydi <te=
ohuiming.work@...> wrote:
> >  Hi Mark,
> >
> > On 11/25/05, Mark Bak=
er <distobj@...> wrote:
> > >  I know Roy and I have argued about this =
point, but I continue to believe
> > > this to be somewhat "bad" as it expo=
ses the client to the implementation
> > > details of the server by assumin=
g that the data in the POST response
> > > constitutes a response to the qu=
ery in the POST request.  Consider that with
> > > such an assumption, one =
couldn't readily substitute another Web server and
> > > still have it meet=
 the same expectation.
>
>  I mean that if I POST "a=3D3" to a URI, and I g=
et back "fred", in either the POST(a) or
> POST(p) case, there's no relatio=
nship between the "4" and the "a=3D3" because neither
> POST(a) nor POST(p)=
 provide any visibility into that relationship.
>
>  So if a POST of "a=3D3=
" is used to query for "the names of all contained resources
> whose proper=
ty 'a' has value '3'", and the client interprets "fred" as such a name, the=
n
> that's an interpretation of the response message which isn't licensed b=
y any
> specification.

C: GET /foo/my/portfolio

S: 200 OK
S: <form method=
=3D"POST" action=3D"/foo/analyzer">
S:   ...portfolio...
S:   <input type=
=3D"submit" value=3D"Analyze" />
S: </form>

C: POST /foo/analyzer
C: ...po=
rtfolio...

S: 200 OK
S: Content-Type: application/portfolio-analysis
S: ..=
.

The response is identified as a portfolio analysis. And RFC 2616 seems
t=
o allow me to assume that the entity in the 200 response is the
actual resu=
lt of the POST:

    9.5 POST
       [...]
       The actual function perfo=
rmed by the POST method is determined by the
       server and is usually d=
ependent on the Request-URI. [...]

       The action performed by the POST=
 method might not result in a
       resource that can be identified by a U=
RI. In this case, either 200
       (OK) or 204 (No Content) is the appropr=
iate response status,
       depending on whether or not the response inclu=
des an entity that
       describes the result.

    10.2.1 200 OK

       =
The request has succeeded. The information returned with the response
     =
  is dependent on the method used in the request, for example:

       GET =
   an entity corresponding to the requested resource is sent in
           =
   the response;
       [...]
       POST   an entity describing or contain=
ing the result of the action;

I don't see a problem substituting another w=
eb server, as long as "the
actual function performed by the POST method" is=
 the same for the
targeted Request-URI. What's missing?
